option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Sudoku solution verifier

Sudoku is a number-placement puzzle. The goal is to fill a $9\times 9$ grid with digits so that each row, each column, and each of the nine $3\times 3$ boxes (as shown in the diagram below) contain all of the digits from 1 to 9. In this problem, we will write a program that verifies the correctness of a solution to a Sudoku puzzle.

The verification steps are as follows:
  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.
If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct. Consider the following examples:
  • This grid has duplicate 8s in the second row, so the program should output that row 2 is incorrect, even if row 6 also has duplicate 1s. \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c||c|c|c||c|c|c} 1 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 8 & 3 & 5 & 6 & 4 \\\hline 4 & 6 & \color{red}{8} & 5 & 7 & 2 & 9 & \color{red} 8 & 3 \\\hline 5 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 1 & 4 & 8 & 7 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 5 & 6 & 4 & 9 & 7 \\\hline 8 & 4 & 6 & 3 & 9 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 \\\hline 9 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 4 & 1 & 3 & 1 & 6 \\\hline\hline 6 & 8 & 4 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 \\\hline 3 & 9 & 1 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 7 & 2 & 5 \\\hline 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 4 & 8 \end{array} \]
  • This grid has duplicate 5s in the seventh column, so the program should output that column 7 is incorrect, even if column 9 also has duplicate 7s. \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c||c|c|c||c|c|c} 1 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 8 & 3 & \color{red}5 & 6 & 4 \\\hline 4 & 6 & 8 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 1 & 3 \\\hline 5 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 1 & 4 & 8 & 7 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 5 & 6 & 4 & 9 & 7 \\\hline 8 & 4 & 6 & 3 & 9 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 \\\hline 9 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 4 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 6 \\\hline\hline 6 & 8 & 4 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 \\\hline 3 & 9 & 1 & 4 & 6 & 8 & \color{red}5 & 2 & 7 \\\hline 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 4 & 8 \end{array} \]
  • This grid has duplicate 2s in the fourth box, so the program should output that box 4 is incorrect, even if box 7 also has duplicate 9s. \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c||c|c|c||c|c|c} 1 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 8 & 3 & 5 & 6 & 4 \\\hline 4 & 6 & 8 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 1 & 3 \\\hline 5 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 1 & 4 & 8 & 7 & 2 \\\hline\hline 7 & \color{red}2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 4 & 8 \\\hline \color{red}2 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 5 & 6 & 4 & 9 & 7 \\\hline 8 & 4 & 6 & 3 & 9 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 \\\hline\hline 9 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 4 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 6 \\\hline 6 & 8 & 4 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 \\\hline 3 & 9 & 1 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 7 & 2 & 5 \end{array} \]
  • This grid is a completely valid solution to a Sudoku puzzle. \[ \begin{array}{c|c|c||c|c|c||c|c|c} 1 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 8 & 3 & 5 & 6 & 4 \\\hline 4 & 6 & 8 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 9 & 1 & 3 \\\hline 5 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 1 & 4 & 8 & 7 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 5 & 6 & 4 & 9 & 7 \\\hline 8 & 4 & 6 & 3 & 9 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 \\\hline 9 & 5 & 7 & 2 & 4 & 1 & 3 & 8 & 6 \\\hline\hline 6 & 8 & 4 & 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 \\\hline 3 & 9 & 1 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 7 & 2 & 5 \\\hline 7 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 9 & 6 & 4 & 8 \end{array} \]

option.name: text
option.value: // No code to write for this task. See task description on the right.

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Sudoku quiz

Suppose we consider a variant of the Sudoku puzzle, where the grid is of size $4\times 4$. Consider the following grid: \[ \begin{array}{c|c||c|c} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\\hline 3 & 4 & 1 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 3 & 2 & 1 \\\hline 4 & 1 & 4 & 3 \end{array} \] What should be the expected output from the solution verifier?
The verification steps are as follows:
  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.
If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Sudoku quiz

Suppose we consider a variant of the Sudoku puzzle, where the grid is of size $4\times 4$. Consider the following grid: \[ \begin{array}{c|c||c|c} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\\hline 3 & 1 & 4 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 3 & 4 & 1 \\\hline 4 & 1 & 2 & 3 \end{array} \] What should be the expected output from the solution verifier?
The verification steps are as follows:
  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.
If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Sudoku quiz

Suppose we consider a variant of the Sudoku puzzle, where the grid is of size $4\times 4$. Consider the following grid: \[ \begin{array}{c|c||c|c} 3 & 4 & 1 & 2 \\\hline 2 & 3 & 4 & 1 \\\hline\hline 4 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\\hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \end{array} \] What should be the expected output from the solution verifier?
The verification steps are as follows:
  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.
If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Sudoku quiz

Suppose we consider a variant of the Sudoku puzzle, where the grid is of size $4\times 4$. Consider the following grid: \[ \begin{array}{c|c||c|c} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\\hline 3 & 4 & 1 & 2 \\\hline\hline 2 & 3 & 4 & 1 \\\hline 4 & 1 & 2 & 3 \end{array} \] What should be the expected output from the solution verifier?
The verification steps are as follows:
  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.
If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Preparing for verification

The first part of this programming exercise asks you to check whether an array of length 9 contains all numbers from 1 to 9, each appearing exactly once.

Complete the method hasOneThroughNine() in class OneThruNine, by filling in parts that say /* TODO */, so that it returns true if the given array of length 9 contains every number from 1 to 9, and false otherwise.

You may assume that the array argument is always of length 9. In fact, the provided code already checks this for you. You may further assume that every number in the array is always in range [1, 9].

The method works by keeping track of the numbers that we have seen in appropriate slots of the present array. If any number appears more than once, the array slot would have been set to true, and the method can immediately return false. On the other hand, if any number does not appear in the array, that means some other number must appear more than once, because we know that the array is of length 9, and all numbers in the array are in range [1, 9].

Java arrays are like C++ arrays, where the first element is at index 0. If you try to access an array element that is out of range, you will see an error called ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
The enhanced for loop goes through each element in the array, starting from the first element. For example, the following loop prints 2 6 1 2 0 0 to the console: 

    int[] arr = {2, 6, 1, 2, 0, 0};
    for (int x : arr)
      System.out.print(x + " ");

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Checking rows

In this part of the exercise, we will start checking the validity of Sudoku grids by verifying that every row is valid. A row is valid if it contains every number from 1 to 9.

Complete the method checkRows() in class RowChecker, by filling in parts that say /* TODO */, so that it returns true if every row in the given grid is valid, and false otherwise. Moreover, if there is an invalid row, the method should print the row number of the first invalid row.

You may assume that the argument is always a 9x9 2-dimensional array. You may further assume that every number in the grid is always in range [1, 9].

The method works by first constructing an array that contains numbers in a certain row, which is then passed to the method hasOneThroughNine().

You might see parts of the code that say /* AUTOFILL */. These parts are copied from your solutions to the previous programming exercises. Be sure you have checked and passed those exercises before trying this one.

This is an illustration of the Sudoku grid from earlier:
As before, Java arrays start from index 0. On the contrary, Sudoku rows start from row 1.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Checking columns

In this part of the exercise, we will continue checking the validity of Sudoku grids by verifying that every column is valid. A column is valid if it contains every number from 1 to 9.

Complete the method checkColumns() in class ColumnChecker, by filling in parts that say /* TODO */, so that it returns true if every column in the given grid is valid, and false otherwise. Moreover, if there is an invalid column, the method should print the column number of the first invalid column.

You may assume that the argument is always a 9x9 2-dimensional array. You may further assume that every number in the grid is always in range [1, 9].

The method works by first constructing an array that contains numbers in a certain column, which is then passed to the method hasOneThroughNine().

You might see parts of the code that say /* AUTOFILL */. These parts are copied from your solutions to the previous programming exercises. Be sure you have checked and passed those exercises before trying this one.

This is an illustration of the Sudoku grid from earlier:
As before, Java arrays start from index 0. On the contrary, Sudoku columns start from column 1.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Checking boxes

In this part of the exercise, we will finish up checking the validity of Sudoku grids by verifying that every box is valid. A box is valid if it contains every number from 1 to 9.

Complete the method checkBoxes() in class BoxChecker, by filling in parts that say /* TODO */, so that it returns true if every box in the given grid is valid, and false otherwise. Moreover, if there is an invalid box, the method should print the box number of the first invalid box.

You may assume that the argument is always a 9x9 2-dimensional array. You may further assume that every number in the grid is always in range [1, 9].

The method works by first constructing an array that contains numbers in a certain box, which is then passed to the method hasOneThroughNine().

You might see parts of the code that say /* AUTOFILL */. These parts are copied from your solutions to the previous programming exercises. Be sure you have checked and passed those exercises before trying this one.

This is an illustration of the Sudoku grid from earlier:

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Putting everything together

In the last part of this programming exercise, we will build a Sudoku solution verifier, using the code we have written in the previous parts.

As a reminder, the verification steps are as follows:

  • Verify whether each row is correct. If not, display the row number of the first incorrect row.
  • If all rows are correct, verify whether each column is correct. If not, display the column number of the first incorrect column.
  • If all rows and columns are correct, verify whether each box is correct. If not, display the box number of the first incorrect box.

If no rows, columns, or boxes violate the correctness conditions, we will declare that the solution is correct.

Complete the method isValidGrid() in class SudokuVerifier, by filling in parts that say /* TODO */, so that it returns true if the given grid is valid, and false otherwise. Moreover, if the grid is invalid, the method should display a message according to the specifications above.

You may assume that the argument is always a 9x9 2-dimensional array. You may further assume that every number in the grid is always in range [1, 9].

You might see parts of the code that say /* AUTOFILL */. These parts are copied from your solutions to the previous programming exercises. Be sure you have checked and passed those exercises before trying this one.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Displaying a spacecraft

Your first internship is in a game development company. The company is trying to create a game involving spacecrafts. Your first job is to design how to represent a spacecraft so that you can display it on the screen properly.

In this lab, you will write a class that will help us display a spacecraft on the screen. For now, let's assume that spacecrafts travel in a 2-dimensional plane. Take a look at the class Spacecraft as provided. The class currently contains four fields:

  • x: the x-coordinate of the spacecraft
  • y: the y-coordinate of the spacecraft
  • width: the width of the spacecraft
  • height: the height of the spacecraft

All these fields are integers.

Next, we will start adding constructors to create spacecrafts for use in our game. Click "Next" to continue. Do not click "Run" or you will not be able to proceed.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
A class without any declared constructor, like one provided here, contains a "default" constructor you can invoke using a "class instance creation expression" to create a new object (and assign the result to a variable): 

Spacecraft s = new Spacecraft();
This invocation initialize all the fields to their "default" values. For int, the default value is 0.

Nevertheless, we usually need to initialize certain fields to a meaningful value. In our case, the default constructor initialize the dimension (width and height) of the spacecraft to zero, which does not quite make sense.

Implement a constructor that does not take any argument, so that when invoked, it constructs a spacecraft that has both the width and the height of size 1 (the initial position is still at the origin).

Be sure to write your code within the grey box so it shows up in later exercises.

Click on the "Check" button to check your answer.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value: Implement a constructor that takes one argument of type int, so that when invoked, it constructs a spacecraft whose width and height are equal to the value of the argument. In other words, this constructor creates a square-shaped spacecraft.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
In the last exercise, we wrote a constructor that creates a square-shaped spacecraft. Notice that we now have two constructors, one taking no arguments and the other taking one argument. This is an example of overloading, where a name can mean several things. In our case, we overloaded the constructors of class Spacecraft so that we can create spacecrafts in multiple ways.

Still, we don't have a way to create a spacecraft of any rectangular shape yet. To do so, we add another constructor (i.e., another overloading) that takes two arguments indicating the width and the height of the spacecraft to be created. Complete the body of this constructor.

Observe that the parameter names in the constructors are the same as the names of the object fields. Writing just the name in the constructor body will refer to the parameter and not the field. To refer to the field, use this keyword as a prefix, e.g., this.x.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Having constructed spacecrafts, your game company wants to know how large it is so they can plan to draw it on the screen. To do so, you will write instance methods that compute and return values of interest to the caller.

Java methods are like functions in C++, but are written inside a class declaration.

Write the following two instance methods, both taking no arguments:

  • area(): returns an integer indicating the area of the spacecraft, calculated from its dimension
  • perimeter(): returns an integer indicating the perimeter of the spacecraft

You may assume that the spacecraft is of a rectangular shape.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
In Java, we can call an instance method m of object o using syntax 

o.m(...)

For example, in our Spacecraft class we have written so far, we can obtain the area used by a spacecraft as follows: 


  // construct a huge spacecraft
  Spacecraft s = new Spacecraft(261, 200);
  // print its area on the screen
  System.out.println(s.area());

We can use the Spacecraft class we have written so far to create many spacecrafts of various sizes, but currently, all of them remain at the origin (coordinate (0, 0)). We need to be able to move the spacecraft elsewhere on the 2-dimensional plane.

To do this, we declare another method called setPosition that takes two arguments, the x- and y-coordinates of the new position of the spacecraft. When called, the method should set the spacecraft's position as provided.

Complete the implementation of this method.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Like constructors, instance methods can be overloaded. Overloaded instance methods have the same name, but take different arguments (either the number of arguments, or the types of arguments, or both).

Over the course of the game, a spacecraft can change its size depending on its speed. (Special relativity plays a role here, but we will not worry about the details.) So, we need a way to update the size.

First, write a method called setSize that takes two arguments, the new width and the new height of the spacecraft, both integers, in that order, and update the spacecraft's size accordingly. This method should return nothing (void).

Next, overload the setSize method with another that takes one integer argument that represents both the width and height of the spacecraft, and update the size accordingly. In other words, this method might be invoked when the spacecraft's shapes is becoming a square.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
In the last lab, we embarked on a design of spacecraft representation. Although the code we wrote last time works just fine, there are some design issues we did not consider, that could introduce complications when our codebase gets larger.

Shown alongside this task is the code that you wrote last time. Recall that each spacecraft is located in a 2-dimensional plane specified by (x, y) coordinates. In other words, knowing just the x- or the y-coordinate of the spacecraft doesn't help us locate it. We need a way to guarantee that when we ask for the location of a spacecraft, we always get both its x- and y-coordinates.

To achieve this, we use a concept called encapsulation, that will put all the data belonging to the same component into one place. To put this in a Java context, we will create a class that will represent a point in the 2-dimensional plane.

In fact, we have employed encapsulation already. The class Spacecraft that we have written is exactly an encapsulation of the data needed for displaying a spacecraft on the screen. Nevertheless, the concept of encapsulation should be applied repeatedly, to make our code as modular as possible, i.e., each component belongs to its own object.

In the first part of this lab, we will explore the idea of encapsulation, which will then let us talk about abstraction and access protection.

option.name: text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
First, we will create a class called Point that will let us encapsulate the coordinates of a spacecraft.

Write a constructor that takes the x- and y-coordinates (as integers, in that order) of a point in the 2-dimensional plane. Declare fields as appropriate and make them private, so that client code cannot change the coordinates arbitrarily.

Then, complete the body of instance methods getX and getY to return the appropriate coordinate of a Point object. Observe that these methods have been declared public so that any code can use it. Since the primary goal of these methods is to fetch and return some properties of an object, they are called getters.

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Now that we have created the Point class, we can use it in our program. We will perform a process called refactoring, in which we modify our code to use the new design.

Modify class Spacecraft to use Point. Declare new field(s) as appropriate. Remove unnecessary fields after refactoring. Again, be sure to make all the fields private to prevent client code from changing our spacecraft specs arbitrarily.

You will need to modify constructors and methods to create and use Point objects.

Next, write the following getters, which are all public:

  • position(): returns the current position of the spacecraft as a Point
  • width(): returns the width of the spacecraft
  • height(): returns the height of the spacecraft

option.name: placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Now that we have written a few classes. We can start to write a program that we can execute as a standalone.

Take a look at the Main class, shown alongside this task description. This class contains a main method that will act as the entry point to the program. This program simply creates a spacecraft, and then tries to print the object on the screen.

You will see a green "play" button next to the line number at the top of the file. Clicking on it, you will see option "Run Main.main()" at the top. Choosing this option will execute the program. Alternatively, you can click on the "Run" button at the bottom of the task description (but you can't always do this for every task). You will probably see an output that looks similar to this: 

Spacecraft@4554617c

This is the default output when trying to print an object. As you can see, it doesn't give us a lot of idea about the object we are trying to print out. In the next section, we will customize what's to be printed when an object is passed to the println method.

The main method receives an array of String as arguments. These arguments correspond to the command-line options the user enters. The method println means to print a newline when we are done. The method that doesn't print a newline is called print. These methods belong to object System.out. We will talk about what static means later.

Click "Next" to continue.

option.name: text
placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
To display more useful information of a Spacecraft object, we add a public method called toString() to the class as follows: 


    public String toString() {
        return "Spacecraft at position " + pos +
                ", with width " + width() + " and height " + height();
    }

Run the main method again. You will see that the output becomes a little more useful, like the following: 

Spacecraft at position Point@4554617c, with width 20 and height 19

Notice that we know a bit more about the spacecraft, like its dimension. Still, we don't quite have a good idea of where it is, so we should display its location more properly.

Modify the code so that the output of the main method becomes 

Spacecraft at position (0, 0), with width 20 and height 19
Avoid modifying the toString() method in Spacecraft. Think modular!

This seems like the same problem when we try to print a Spacecraft object in the main method. Which class should we work on in this case?

option.name: text
placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
When we declare fields private, we are essentially preventing client code from accessing object properties directly. As we saw earlier, client code can only read these properties via getter methods, like getX() in class Point. What if we want to modify these properties? We need to use setter methods.

In fact, we've already seen setters earlier, in the previous lab, when we implemented setPosition and setSize methods in class Spacecraft. There, our goal is to change the position of a spacecraft or its dimensions.

After refactoring, we encapsulated the position of a spacecraft into a Point object. Now, we don't have setters for Point yet, so we might be tempted to write one. But we need to be careful. Simply adding setters to the class can lead to unintended consequences. Consider the following code: 


  Spacecraft s = new Spacecraft();
  Point p = s.position(); // p is (0, 0)
  p.setX(261200); // now p is (261200, 0)
  System.out.println(s.position()); // (261200, 0)!
What's happening here is that arbitrary code can change the properties of a spacecraft in an implicit way. This scenario is undesirable, because the spacecraft itself doesn't know that its property is being changed. In other words, we are violating the abstraction barrier between a spacecraft object and client code, because changing a spacecraft's position should be done through the spacecraft object itself.

To avoid breaking abstraction barriers, we can't directly implement setters for Point. Instead, we will implement mutators that will create a new object that contains almost all the existing properties, but with some fields modified. Hence, mutators are methods that takes the new value of a property, and returns a new object of the same type, but with that property modified to a new value.

Write the following two mutators for class Point:

  • mutateX: takes the new x-coordinate as the only argument, and returns a Point object that represents the new position.
  • mutateY: takes the new y-coordinate as the only argument, and returns a Point object that represents the new position.

option.name: text
text
placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Although a spacecraft object stores just a few things, namely, its position and dimensions, we can compute other derived properties that might be useful.

For example, knowing the position and dimensions, we can compute the bounding box for graphically displaying the spacecraft on the screen. A bounding box is a rectangle that encompasses the entire object when drawn. In our case, the bounding box dimensions are approximately the dimensions of the spacecraft itself. (We will see why they are "approximate" in a moment.)

So far, we have not been clear about what the "position" of a spacecraft means, so let's clear that up. The position is assumed to be the center of the spacecraft. Therefore, when a 4x4 spacecraft is centered at the origin, the left end of the bounding box is at coordinate -2, and the right end is at coordinate 2, and similarly for the vertical dimension. Since the bounding box is always a rectangle, we can represent a bounding box using two points: the lower-left coordinates and the upper-right coordinates.

One complication from representing the bounding box this way is that our representation of Point is discrete: coordinates can only be integers. So, we need to be careful when a dimension of a spacecraft is an odd number. We need the bounding box to cover the entire spacecraft, but no more than necessary.

With that complication in mind, write the following methods in class Spacecraft that compute the bounding box as a derived property:

  • lowerLeft(): returns the lower-left coordinates of the bounding box
  • upperRight(): returns the upper-right coordinates of the bounding box
You'll need to do some math to come up with formulas that describe these two points.

Notice that it takes some thinking (both from us and by the computer) to compute such a derived property. Another way to avoid computing derived properties repeatedly is to cache the result in a new field. In this way, there's a tradeoff between computation time to come up with the result and memory used to store the result. Although we save some time by storing results, these values become invalid once we update the original properties, and we need to recompute these results. When writing a large application, we should determine whether updates are frequent. Caching derived properties is more appropriate when updates are rare, while computing derived properties on the fly is more appropriat when updates are frequent.

option.name: placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
In the last lab, we learned about properties of objects, which we can store as fields (alternatively called instance variables. In this lab, we will learn how to store properties of a class. These properties don't depend on specific objects, but rather on classes as a whole.

In our spacecraft game, we might want to keep track of how many spacecrafts are flying out there. You can see that this number does not belong to any spacecraft in particular, but rather to the whole system of spacecrafts. Therefore, storing this information as a field is inappropriate. Instead, when we construct a spacecraft, we should note that there is one more spacecraft in the system.

The number of spacecrafts that have been created can be represented by a static field (alternatively called class variable). These variables are like fields for objects, but instead declared using the keyword static before their types.

First, declare a static field that will help us keep track of the number of spacecrafts we have created. Be sure to make this field private to prevent arbitrary code from changing the number of spacecrafts to an incorrect number.

Then, think about how to actually keep track of the number of spacecrafts we have created. You will need to modify existing code somewhere. That's for you to figure out.

Finally, write a static getter method to return the number of spacecrafts. Like before, static methods (alternatively called class methods) are like methods we have seen before (alternatively called instance methods), but with the keyword static before the return type. Static methods can only refer to static fields, while instance methods can refer to both. Be sure to make the method public so that anyone can query the number of spacecrafts in the system.

Hints can be added anywhere in task text: type "hint" and press Tab.

option.name: placeholderText
possibleAnswer
text
text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Similar to derived (object) properties, classes can compute derived properties of their own.

In our spacecraft game, one interesting property is called the viewport, which is the rectangle that encompasses all spacecrafts in the system. If a spacecraft flies farther away from the rest, then the viewport gets bigger. To simplify this problem, we will assume that the viewport only grows. For instance, when the spacecraft at the corner of the universe flies back to the center of the universe, the viewport does not shrink. On the other hand, if this spacecraft flies out even further, the viewport will have to expand.

Once again, we can represent the viewport by its lower-left and upper-right points, like we did for the bounding box of a spacecraft. With this design in mind, complete the implementation of the following methods in class Spacecraft:

  • viewportLowerLeft():
    • returns the lower-left corner of the current viewport of the spacecraft system
  • viewportUpperRight():
    • returns the upper-right corner of the current viewport of the spacecraft system

As usual, you will need to modify existing code to make the computation of the viewport correct.

We will assume that the viewport of the system without any spacecrafts is just the origin (0, 0).

In the last lab, we can choose to compute the value of derived properties on the fly or cache it. Can we do the same here, or do we need to do both? What are the tradeoffs between the two approaches in this scenario?
